A set is a collection of distinct objects considered as an entity.
Two cycles $(x_{1}, \ldots, x_{r})$ and $(y_{1}, \ldots, y_{s})$ are called disjoint if the sets $\{x_{1}, \ldots, x_{r}\}$ and $\{y_{1}, \ldots, y_{s}\}$ have no elements in common.
Does the concept of a/an Set need to be defined for a definition of a/an Disjoint Cycles to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The definition of Disjoint Cycles explicitly uses the concept of a Set. It states that two cycles are disjoint if the sets of elements in each cycle have no elements in common. This requires understanding what a set is, as it involves the collection of elements from each cycle and checking for common elements between these collections. Without the concept of a set, it would not be possible to form these collections or to understand the notion of having no elements in common, which is central to the definition of disjoint cycles.
